summary.seg:
Manuscript Kk.5.8 contains a collection of Scholia on Oppian's Halieutica
("On fishing"), a didactic poem in hexameter on sea-creatures and fishing from the 2nd century CE, followed by an anonymous grammatical work on accents attributed to Theodosius of Alexandria.

The codex was probably copied in France, as the watermarks and the fact that it was owned by Jean-Baptiste Hautin suggest. The text was coped by a scribe who signed the copy of the last text in November 1592; although the colophon refers explicitly only to this text, since the rest of the manuscript has been written by the same scribe on the same kind of paper, the same period can be hypothesised for the copy af the whole manuscript.
Manuscript Kk.5.6 is currently bound as the third part of a single volume with three other manuscripts, Kk.5.6, 7 and 9.

msItem.title: Life of Oppian
Vita Oppiani
msItem.incipit: f. 3r Ὀππιανὸς ὁ ποιητὴς πατρὸς μὲν ἦν Ἀγησιλάου, μητρὸς δὲ Ζηνοδότης, τὸ γένος ἀπὸ Nαζάρβου τῆς Κιλικίας
msItem.explicit: f. 3r l. 28 τυγχάνει δὲ μάλιστα ἐν ταῖς γνωμολογίαις τε καὶ παραβολαῖς ἄριστος
msItem.note: Vita Tzetziana e codd. Laur. gr. 31.3, Ambros. gr. C 222 inf., Vat. gr. 1345
A. Colonna, 'De vita Oppiani antiquissima', in: Bollettino del comitato per la preparazione dell'edizione nazionale dei classici greci e latini 12 (1964), p. 40

msItem.title: Scholia on Oppian's Halieutica
Scholia in Oppiani Halieutica
msItem.incipit: f. 3r l. 28 Διαλαμβάνει ἐν μὲν τῷ πρώτῳ τῶν ἁλιευτικῶν μετὰ τὸ προοίμιον
msItem.explicit: f. 29r l. 8 Ἀσφάλιος· ῥιζοῦχος δὲ ὁ συνέχων τὰς ῥίζας τῶν οἴκων τυγχάνει δὲ μάλιστα ἐν ταῖς γνωμολογίαις τε καὶ παραβολαῖς
msItem.finalRubric: f. 29r l. 10 Τέλος τοὺ πέμπτου τῶν ἁλιευτικῶν τοῦ Ὀππιανοῦ

msItem.title: Life of Theocritus, Composition of the Idylls (from the Scholia vetera on Theocritus)
Vita Theocriti, Scholia in Theocritum
msItem.incipit: f. 29r Θεόκριτος ὁ τῶν βουκολικῶν ποιητής
msItem.explicit: f. 29r l. 36 ταῖς ἀγροικοῖς ὀδαῖς τόπον ἔδωκαν
msItem.note: K. Wendel, Scholia in Theocritum vetera, Leipzig 1914, pp. 1-352, sections Aa and Ba

msItem.title: De Prosodiis
msItem.rubric: f. 30r Ἑρωτήματα Θεοδοσίου γραμματικοῦ περὶ προσῳδιῶν
msItem.incipit: f. 30r Προσῳδίαι εἰσὶ δέκα· ὀξεῖα ´, βαρεῖα `, περισπωμένη ῀, μακρά –
msItem.finalRubric: f. 40v Τέλος τῶν ἑρωτημάτων Θεοδοσίου γραμματικοῦ περὶ προσῳδιῶν
msItem.note:
The text, as in other manuscripts, is attributed to
Theodosius Alexandrinus Theodosius Alexandrinus , but is is believed to be spurious, see Uhlig (1883), p. XXXIX
See, attributed to the same Theodosius, G. Uhlig, Grammatici Graeci, 1.1, Leipzig 1883 (repr. Hildesheim 1965), pp. 105-132 (TLG 0072.001): only the beginning however is the same

msItem.title: Colophon
msItem.colophon: Transcripsi ex veteri codice manuscripto cum nondum typis excusus in lucem prodiisset hic Theodosius mense Novembri 1592

support.material:
Western paper, folded in folio . Watermarks:
ff. i, 42-43 Coat of arms formed by the shields of France and Navarre in a circular wreath surmountrd by a quatrefoil; below the name G IOVRNEE in a cartouche (it is the name of Guillaume Journée, paper-maker of Troyes, see Briquet) ( 80 40 ) in the centre of the leaf, comparable to Briquet Armoiries 1854-1855 , by the same miller, which are dated 1582-1624 and 1595-1602.
ff. 2-41 Name
J NIVELLE in a cartouche ( 33 10 ) in the centre of the leaf, very similar to Briquet Noms de lieux et de personnes 12059 , which is dated to ca. 1553-1566 in France.

supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, in the upper margin, right, recto, in Arabic numerals from 2 to 43; ff. i, 42 and 43 are endleaves: i + 2-43.

collation.p: The quires are sewn tightly, and there are no signatures or catchwords, therefore the collation has been reconstructed with the help of the watermarks.

supportDesc.condition:
The codex has been bound together with MSS
Cambridge, Univeristy Library, Kk.5.6 ,
Kk.5.7 , and
Kk.5.9 . The spine is broken, and the textblock is split in four parts. As for MS Kk.5.8 in particular, it is in fair condition. The leaves are slightly yellowed near the edges. There are a few wormholes near the gutter.

handNote.p: ff. 2r, 3r-29r, 30r, 31r-40v Hand A: the text has been written entirely in a minuscule script slightly slanting to the right, by a scribe who probably had a western-European origin, as showed, besides the script, by the fact that he wrote a colophon in Latin.
The text is written in brown ink.

additions.p: On f. 1r the shelfmark Kk.5.8 is written in pencil.
On f. 2r, in the upper part of the leaf, right, is written the shelfmark Kk.5.8 in brown ink.

On f. 2v, there is a list of the contents of the manuscript in the hand which recurs in the manuscripts owned by J.B. Hautin (see Provenance): Scholia in Oppiani halieutica Theodosius grammaticus de prosodia.

binding.p: Modern western binding. Paper over couched-laminate boards. Leather spine tooled in gold with title Miscellanea Graece M.S. and shelfmark only partially readable Kk.5.6 .
A leather page marker is placed on f. 30 to open the book where a new text begins.
binding.condition: The boards are loose. The textblock split in four parts, the spine is broken.

origin.p: On f. 30r the scribe wrote a colophon with the date of November 1592, which refers only to the second text of the manuscript; however, since the first text has been written by the same hand on the same kind of paper (see Watermarks), it can be assumed that the whole manuscript originated around 1592. It was probably copied in France, as the watermarks suggest.

provenance.p: The manuscript was owned by a certain J.B. Hautin, probably to be identified with Jean Baptiste II Hautin, son of the French scholar and numismatist Haultin, Jean-Baptiste, approximately 1580-1640 Jean-Baptiste Hautin (ca. 1580-1640) : on f. 2v there is a small table of contents, written by the hand, which occurs in almost all Hautin's manuscripts (see also Jackson 2006, p. 30).

It passed afterwards to John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : number 978 (c.10) in the handwritten supplementary list of Moore's manuscripts, now MS Oo.7.50(2), compiled by Thomas Tanner (1674-1735) after the publication of C. Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697).

history.acquisition: The manuscript was presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 . On the left pastedown is pasted the engraved bookplate made by John Pine for the Royal Library .

recordHist.source: Description (2021) draws partly on A catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, vol. 3: Gg-Kk, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1858, pp. 677-678.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: A catalogue of the manuscripts preserved in the library of the University of Cambridge

analytic.title: The Greek Manuscripts of John Moore and Etienne Baluze
